items.title: Five Years Into a Fishing Ban, the Yangtze River Is Teeming With Life
items.description: Flowing almost 4,000 miles from the Tibetan Plateau to the East China Sea, the Yangtze is China’s “Mother River.” From the emerald-green rice paddies of Hunan to the industrial hubs of Wuhan and Shanghai, the river basin generates 40 percent of the nation’s economic output. items.title: ‘The Sky Isn’t Falling’: Providing Perspective on the Data Center Boom
items.description: The rise of AI data centers has sparked panic about how to provide enough electricity to support new development without overheating the planet and saddling everyone with unaffordable utility costs. items.title: China Could Reach Peak Greenhouse Gas Emissions Sooner Than Beijing Planned, New Report Suggests
items.description: Planet-warming emissions from China, currently the world’s largest greenhouse gas polluter, have continued to flatline or fall as cleaner forms of energy outpace coal and gas generation, according to a new analysis published Wednesday. items.description: A Wake County Superior Court judge has ruled against the cities of Asheboro, Greensboro and Reidsville, concluding that state environmental regulators can legally limit the amount of 1,4-dioxane, a likely carcinogen, that they discharge into the drinking water supply.
